repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Fixes #34013

Problem:
when diagnostic is set right after EOL, underline handler looks inconsistent compared to other handlers, visually underline is shown starting from the next line. On top of that it's also inconsistent with open_float and jump.

Solution:
clamp starting column position in underline handler to be right before EOL to make it visible and consistent with other handlers, open_float and jump.

comment_data.body: Not really sure if this destroys performance. Should this be cached instead similar to `buf_line_count` metatable in `get_diagnostics`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1566,11 +1566,14 @@ M.handlers.underline = {
         end
       end
 
+      local lines =
+        vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(diagnostic.bufnr, diagnostic.lnum, diagnostic.lnum + 1, true)
+

comment_data.body: instead of this, would it help to allow callers of `vim.hl.range()` to control  `eol` here? https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/322a6d305d088420b23071c227af07b7c1beb41a/runtime/lua/vim/hl.lua#L94-L97
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1566,11 +1566,14 @@ M.handlers.underline = {
         end
       end
 
+      local lines =
+        vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(diagnostic.bufnr, diagnostic.lnum, diagnostic.lnum + 1, true)
+

comment_data.body:
`eol` would mean it would extend to the whole window width like `hl_eol` in extmarks? Initially I thought that would be the right solution, but now I don't think it would look good. It would probably look better if we would add virtual text in such cases, so that visually it would match exact diagnostics' positions.

That said I think either of those would only make it look better without making it more consistent with other handlers and `jump` / `open_float`. `jump` still will move cursor to the last character and `open_float` will also show a float there, even though diagnostic is beyond EOL. Unless `virtualedit` is on, of course.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1566,11 +1566,14 @@ M.handlers.underline = {
         end
       end
 
+      local lines =
+        vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(diagnostic.bufnr, diagnostic.lnum, diagnostic.lnum + 1, true)
+

comment_data.body: I mean would `eol=false` solve the problem. It looks like your workaround here is essentially doing that in a different way.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1566,11 +1566,14 @@ M.handlers.underline = {
         end
       end
 
+      local lines =
+        vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(diagnostic.bufnr, diagnostic.lnum, diagnostic.lnum + 1, true)
+

comment_data.body:
I'm not sure I'm following. I can't really spot the difference between `eol=false` and `eol=true` at least with the example from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34013#issuecomment-2888783802

My workaround moves starting position of the underline so that the last character has the visible underline if diagnostic column happens to be beyond the last character. Without it there is no visible underline at all in the starting line and visually it only starts from the following line.

Diagnostic that's being set in the example from that comment:

```lua
{
  lnum = 1,
  col = 13,
  end_lnum = 2,
  end_col = 8,
  message = 'Miss symbol `,` or `;` .',
  -- ...
}
```

And what it looks like before the current change in this PR

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fadcc54d-2f65-4216-bdb9-f9176a4bd87a)

and after

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4d07c5b1-c08c-44f1-a1b9-c2103f4e537a)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1566,11 +1566,14 @@ M.handlers.underline = {
         end
       end
 
+      local lines =
+        vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(diagnostic.bufnr, diagnostic.lnum, diagnostic.lnum + 1, true)
+

comment_data.body:
should those images be swapped? your problem statement says:

> visually underline is shown starting from the next line
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1566,11 +1566,14 @@ M.handlers.underline = {
         end
       end
 
+      local lines =
+        vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(diagnostic.bufnr, diagnostic.lnum, diagnostic.lnum + 1, true)
+

comment_data.body:
Diagnostic here is set on a line with `foo = 'bar'`, right after the last `'`.

First screenshot shows that without this change there's currently no visible underline anywhere in the `foo = 'bar'` line. Instead it's shown starting only from the following `baz = 'quux',` line.

Second screenshot shows how with the change from this PR an underline being shifted to be right on the last `'` to be visible.

Not sure where the confusion comes from.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1566,11 +1566,14 @@ M.handlers.underline = {
         end
       end
 
+      local lines =
+        vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(diagnostic.bufnr, diagnostic.lnum, diagnostic.lnum + 1, true)
+

comment_data.body:
the confusion is:

1. the 2nd image just looks like a mistake and doesn't seem very important.
2. the pr title is "avoid starting an underline beyond EOL" which sounds like it *doesn't* want to start the underline on the previous line.
3. the pr description just says "looks inconsistent" instead of saying the actual problem.

how is that not confusing?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1566,11 +1566,14 @@ M.handlers.underline = {
         end
       end
 
+      local lines =
+        vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(diagnostic.bufnr, diagnostic.lnum, diagnostic.lnum + 1, true)
+

comment_data.body: Now I see it. Sorry. It wasn't obvious to me that "starting" sounds like it's visible there. I should've described the problem better.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

         end
       end
 
+      local lines =
+        vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(diagnostic.bufnr, diagnostic.lnum, diagnostic.lnum + 1, true)
+

comment_data.body: TODO: after https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/31903 we could add `opts` to `nvim_buf_line_count()` for a more performant way to count lines in a partial buffer.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1581,11 +1581,14 @@ M.handlers.underline = {
         end
       end
 
+      local lines =
+        vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(diagnostic.bufnr, diagnostic.lnum, diagnostic.lnum + 1, true)

comment_regular_data.body: Not really sure where to add a test for it. Doesn't look like there are tests dedicated to an underline handler unless I'm missing something.

> Not really sure if this destroys performance. Should this be cached instead similar to `buf_line_count` metatable in `get_diagnostics`?

Definitely don't want more caches. We are using the [same approach](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/570e62d0f99dbc99e4f506ad1b874bb1842159d0/runtime/lua/vim/diagnostic.lua#L2181-L2182) elsewhere as mentioned in the linked issue.

I wonder if any of this logic could be shared instead of repeated in multiple places...

>Definitely don't want more caches. We are using the [same approach](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/570e62d0f99dbc99e4f506ad1b874bb1842159d0/runtime/lua/vim/diagnostic.lua#L2181-L2182) elsewhere as mentioned in the linked issue.
>
>I wonder if any of this logic could be shared instead of repeated in multiple places...

I have [another PR open](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/34014) which removes the code you linked to. Instead it creates extmarks to track positions of diagnostics and uses it in `open_float` and `jump`. Extmark positions include this workaround as well. We could probably make all handlers use either that extmark's position for handlers or use that single extmark for all handlers, by adding/removing highlighting, virtual text, lines, signs, etc. to reuse this logic.

Though currently extmark end positions in that PR are shifted one column to the left to avoid showing a float after the visible underline. And if we use that extmark for underline, underline itself will be shifted as well. But I'm almost sure that this shifting could be moved to `open_float` instead without affecting anything else.

>shifting could be moved to `open_float` instead without affecting anything else.

Just pushed a commit to do that.

It would now be possible to reuse that position or the extmark itself for handlers, for example, to avoid repeating that workaround in multiple places. I'm not sure if it makes sense to actually do that change in the same PR. I could start working on a new PR on top of it if that approach with using extmarks (or their positions) sounds like a good idea.

title: fix(diagnostics): diagnostic just after EOL is not drawn
